Description: Fragment of a clay seal-impression showing a concave rear with wood impression, probably originating from a peg or knob. In the break two impressions of a turned string with a width of 0.16 cm. The front shows one impression of a scarab-like seal, with the sides of the sealing bending downwards, many finger impressions around it. The seal impression is cut very sharply and shows a circumferential line that thickens at the top. The lower part of the seal is preserved, visible is a bound captive on the left side, kneeling, facing towards the left, with his hands bound together at his back. The head is broken off. Behind him on the right a seated lion, again the head is broken off, with its front paws on the shoulder of the captive. Behind the back of the lion a small upright cobra, facing to the right. Underneath a bound captive, lying on his belly, with his hands and feet bound backwards. The same motif can be found on EA86928, EA86930, EA86931, EA86932, EA86933 and EA86934 as well as on F12793 from year 2014 excavations in Amara West.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Amara West (Nubia), E14.7 temple magazine
Acquisition notes: Formerly housed by the Birmingham Museum and Art Gallery and the EES London.
